title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.12.20 Part 2 | 22-08-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we will discuss the second part of the purport of this twentieth verse.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the session, focusing on the second part of the purport of Srimad Bhagavatam 1.12.20, which discusses charity and protection.

segments.key_quote: There are many Bharatas in history of which three are very famous.
segments.summary: The lecture delves into the history of three famous Bharatas, including the son of Maharaj Dushyanta, the brother of Lord Ramachandra, and the son of King Rishabha.

segments.key_quote: The Vedic scriptures give us knowledge which is comprehensive and vast as compared to the body of knowledge that we have in our modern day.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the comprehensive knowledge of Vedic scriptures with the limited scope of modern-day knowledge, emphasizing the vastness of universal history described in the Vedas.

segments.key_quote: This earth planet is known as Bharata, Bharata Varsha due to King Bharata, the son of Rishabhadeva, the second Bharata I mentioned.
segments.summary: The lecture explains how the earth planet came to be known as Bharata Varsha due to King Bharata, the son of Rishabhadeva, while also highlighting the importance of Bharata, the son of Maharaj Dushyanta.

segments.key_quote: This child Bharata even in his childhood he was so powerful that he challenged the lions and elephants in the forest and would fight with them as little children play with cats and dogs.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Bharata's birth to Shakuntala and Maharaj Dushyanta, and his extraordinary strength as a child growing up in the forest, even comparing him to Tarzan.

segments.key_quote: This boy Bharata is not a fictitious character created by some imaginative story writer. No he is a real person and as a boy he was even more powerful than the so-called Tarzan.
segments.summary: The lecture emphasizes the reality of Bharata's character and his strength, explaining why he was called Sarva Dhaman and how the Pandavas are addressed as Bharata due to their lineage.

segments.key_quote: There is a cycle that is operating in this earth planet.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the importance of performing sacrifices (yaj単a) for the welfare of the kingdom, highlighting the natural cycle of food production, rainfall, and the role of yaj単a in maintaining this balance.

segments.key_quote: So production of grains, sufficient quantity of grains for all creatures, humans and the animals and the other birds etc. depends on proper rainfall.
segments.summary: The lecture elaborates on the dependence of food production on rainfall, which in turn is dependent on the performance of yaj単a, emphasizing the importance of prescribed duties for the welfare of all beings.

segments.key_quote: Duty is something that is prescribed in this jastra for the overall welfare of the entire population of this world.
segments.summary: The speaker stresses that duties are prescribed for the welfare of all, and the king's role in performing yaj単a leads to prosperity for the entire country, foretelling Pariksit's future role.
